Info Habitat: Mixed hardwood and boreal forests of N WI. Often found along Lake Michigan.
Description: Pointy steeple-shaped evergreen tree, to 80' tall; Leaves flat, single, whitish below, 1/4"-3/8" long;  Needles leave flat, circular scar on twig when pulled off or fallen;  Bark with resin blisters; Cones upright, 1.75 - 3.25" long, most prevalent on upper branches. Cone scales fall off, leaving a birthday-candle like stalk on the tree.
Info Uses/Notes: Christmas tree; bow rosin; not good for firewood due to explosive resin

Description: Large 40-60' tree with sharp needles and drooping branchlets. Cones 4-6" long, with scales broader than long.

Info Habitat: Upland forests, esp. in N. Wisconsin;
Description: Tree 50'-60' tall, evergreen; Needles short, on small pegs; Stems hairless; Branchlets not drooping. Cones 1-2" long with broadly rounded scales, dropping when ripe.

Info Habitat: Lowland areas and bogs; mostly in northern 2/3 of state
Description: Tree 25'-30' tall, evergreen; Needles 1/4-1/2" long, often bluish green and whitish; Stems with reddish hairs; Cones small (1 - 1 1/4"), dark grey, pointy when closed, round when older.

Info Habitat: Commonly planted ornamental and yard tree. Native to conifer forests of the Rocky Mountains.
Description: Large tree with  sharp bluish needles.  Cones 4-6" long, with jagged, papery scales.
60'-70' tall, evergreen tree; Needles single, 1/2" long, on tiny short stalks, flat with 2 white lines beneath; Cones small (5/8"-1") with flexible scales.
Info Uses/Notes: Useful as shade-tolerant landscape tree. Threatened by the hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae), an introduced Asian insect. Hemlock also is heavily browsed by deer, and depends upon nurse logs for successful recruitment.

Info Habitat: Found in mesic forest and more common in N WI.

Description: Low, creeping evergreen shrub, 1'-4' tall;  Sharp, 3-sided awl-shaped needles (1/4-7/8" long), plus scale-like needles in whorls of 3 esp. on older growth. Needles sometimes with whitish blue tint; Branchlets 3-sided;  Small, round berry-like cone is blue-black and hard, with whitish hue, smells like gin when crushed.

Spreading, mat-like, evergreen shrub.  Scale-like leaves and sometimes short pointy needles, in whorls of 3. 
Round, blueish berry, up to 3/8" diameter.

Info Habitat: Dry, rocky upland areas; sun-loving, disturbance adapted
Description: Evergreen tree or large shrub with both scale-like and sharp, awl-shaped leaves;  Berry-like cones, blue with whitish wax, odor like gin when crushed; Bark reddish, appears vertically shredded.

Info Habitat: Dry to mesic sites; limestone.  Shade-adapted.
Description: Evergreen treee, 40'-50' tall; branchlets in flattened sprays covered with scale-like leaves 1/16-1/8" long.  Cones small, 1/2" long, brown with few scales.
Info Uses/Notes: Ornamental; Leaves are rich in Vitamin C

Info Habitat: Found in mesic, well-drained soils throughout WI. Our most shade-tolerant native pine.
Description: Large evergreen tree 80'-110' tall with irregular crown and upswept branches; Bark grey with dark deep furrows; Needles 5 per cluster, 2-4" long. Cones woody, 3-10", elongate with open scales often with sticky resin on tips.

Info Habitat: Sandy soils of central and N WI and in pine barrens along WI River. Fire adapted.
Description: Tree 15'-40' tall, evergreen;  Needles 2 per cluster and short, at only 3/4-1 1/2" long. Cones woody, 1-2" long, usually paired on either side of the branch, and curving toward branch tips.
cone placement: cones point towards tip of branches

Info Habitat: Found in pure stands on sandy soils in central and N WI.
Description: Tree 50'-80' tall, evergreen; Needles 2 per cluster, 3-8" long; Bark with pinkish hue; Cones woody, 1.5-2.5" long, broadly rounded.

Info Habitat: Planted in timber plantations on sandy soils
Description: An planted conifer with orange papery bark. Cones point backwards, away from the tips of the branches.

Info Other common names: Eastern larch, American larch, hackmatack, black larch, red larch
Info Habitat: Common in wet forests and bogs of N WI.
Description: Pointy-topped perennial, 40'-80' tall, deciduous tree;  Needles 3/8-1" long in clusters of 10 or more, turn yellow in fall.  Bark flakes off in small scales.  Cones 1/2"-3/4", with few scales.

Info Habitat: Primarily planted as a yard tree, but beginning to naturalize in woodland borders, edges of yards, and moist meadows
Description: Tree 30'-120' tall, with conical shape when young, becoming irregular or oblong with age. Twigs of current year (first 4-20") are pale yellow with alternate leaves. Older twigs are gray to grayish brown with 30-60 needles clustered on short shoots.
